titleproper.value:
Guide to the Town of Flatbush records
                    <num>ARC.031</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-11-22T14:49-0500</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
The Town of Flatbush, one of the six original towns to comprise the present-day borough of Brooklyn, was founded in 1636 when Dutch settlers purchased land from the Native Americans of the region, known as the 
                <emph render="italic">Lenape</emph> (people). Flatbush flourished as a rural farming community until the latter half of the 19th century, when the advent of a system of roads and advances in transportation began to bring commercial influence to the area. With the completion of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883 and Brooklyn's consolidation as a borough of New York City in 1898, the character of Flatbush changed profoundly as waves of New York residents and new immigrants came flooding in to settle in the developing area, transforming it into a thriving suburb. As of 2010, Flatbush is one of the most multicultural neighborhoods of the borough of Brooklyn. The Town of Flatbush records consist of assessment roles recording real and personal estate tax assessments for the years 1839 and 1853, as well as Registers of Electors recording voter names for the years 1860 and 1861. There are also three bound volumes spanning the period 1799 to 1894 and including a list of candidates, reports of election committees, poll lists, minutes of meetings of the Electors, and minutes of annual town meetings.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Town of Flatbush records, ARC.031, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Gift of the Brooklyn Board of Elections, 1897; the Kings County Historical Society, date unknown; and Cathleen K. Morin, 1974.

The Town of Flatbush was founded in 1636 when Dutch settlers purchased land from the Native Americans of the region, known as the 
                <emph render="italic">Lenape</emph> (people), and began to populate what they designated as 
                <emph render="italic">Vlacke Bos</emph> ("flatlands covered with bushes"). In 1652, the governor of New Amsterdam (later New York), Peter Stuyvesant, granted the inhabitants of 
                <emph render="italic">Vlacke Bos</emph> a patent, and the town was officially chartered, becoming one of the original six villages to comprise what would eventually become the borough of Brooklyn, along with Brooklyn, Flatlands, New Utrecht, Bushwick, and Gravesend. In little time, 
                <emph render="italic">Vlacke Bos</emph> began flourishing as a farming community. When the British wrestled long-term control over New Amsterdam from the Dutch in 1674 and renamed the island New York, they also Anglicized the names of the surrounding area's smaller towns and villages; hence, 
                <emph render="italic">Vlacke Bos</emph> became Flatbush. Later in 1683, when the English consolidated the six original towns of Brooklyn under the jurisdiction of Kings County, they designated Flatbush as the county's judicial center, a designation it held for the next 150 years. Still, very little else in Flatbush changed; despite a period of hardship during the Revolutionary War, it largely remained a prosperous rural farming community well into the nineteenth century. Only in the latter half of the nineteenth century, with the advent of a system of roads and advances in transportation, did Flatbush begin to expand and show signs of commercial influence. With the completion of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883 and Brooklyn's consolidation as a borough of New York City in 1898, the character of Flatbush changed profoundly as waves of New York residents and new immigrants came flooding in to settle in the developing area, transforming it into a thriving suburb. As of 2010, Flatbush is one of the most multicultural neighborhoods of the borough of Brooklyn.

The Town of Flatbush records consist of assessment roles recording real and personal estate tax assessments for the years 1839 and 1853, as well as Registers of Electors recording voter names for the years 1860 and 1861. There are also three bound volumes spanning the period 1799 to 1894 and including a list of candidates, reports of election committees, poll lists, minutes of meetings of the Electors, and minutes of annual town meetings. Many prominent Brooklyn individuals and family names are represented in these records, including Henry Woolsy, John Vanderveer, the Wyckoff family, the Ditmars family, Stephen Voorhees, and the Van Siclen family, among many others.
